children.text: The main function reads some inputs: n, then n strings into a 2D array ss, then a string cc, a character c. Then it processes these to replace certain characters in cc based on some conditions.

children.text: The compare function compares two character arrays starting at i and j for m characters, case-insensitively. If they differ, returns the difference; otherwise 0.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The compare function in Java is comparing a substring of aa starting at i with a substring of bb starting at j, for m characters, case-insensitively.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: In Fortran, we can create a function that takes the starting indices and the length m, then loops through each character, converting to uppercase and comparing.

children.text: Then, the main function checks for occurrences of any of the ss[i] in cc, case-insensitively, and marks those positions as lucky.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, for each lucky position, if the original character is c (case-insensitive), replace it with 'a' or 'b' depending on c, else replace with c. Also preserving the case.

logical function is_upper(ch)
    character, intent(in) :: ch
    is_upper = (ch >= 'A' .and. ch <= 'Z')
end function

character function to_upper(ch)
    character, intent(in) :: ch
    if (ch >= 'a' .and. ch <= 'z') then
        to_upper = achar(iachar(ch) - 32)
    else
        to_upper = ch
    end if
end function

children.text:
Thus, after processing, the code can print cc(1:len_cc). Putting it all together. Now, the code structure in Fortran:

module utils
    implicit none
contains
    logical function is_upper(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        is_upper = (ch >= 'A' .and. ch <= 'Z')
    end function

    character function to_upper(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        if (ch >= 'a' .and. ch <= 'z') then
            to_upper = achar(iachar(ch) - 32)
        else
            to_upper = ch
        end if
    end function

    character function to_lower(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        if (ch >= 'A' .and. ch <= 'Z') then
            to_lower = achar(iachar(ch) + 32)
        else
            to_lower = ch
        end if
    end function
end module utils

program main
    use utils
    implicit none

    integer :: n, i, j, k, l, len_cc
    character(len=1000), allocatable :: ss(:)
    integer, allocatable :: ss_lengths(:)
    character(len=1000) :: cc, temp_str
    character :: c, c_lower, c_upper, a_char, a_upper, a_lower
    logical, allocatable :: lucky(:)

    !
children.label: code_analysis

Preprocess cc length
    len_cc = len_trim(cc)

    ! Determine a_char based on c
    c_lower = to_lower(c)
    if (c_lower == 'a') then
        a_char = 'b'
    else
        a_char = 'a'
    end if
    a_upper = to_upper(a_char)
    a_lower = to_lower(a_char)
    c_upper = to_upper(c)
    c_lower = to_lower(c)

    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Initialize lucky array
    allocate(lucky(len_cc)) lucky = .false.

    ! Mark lucky positions
    do j = 1, len_cc do i = 1, n
            l = ss_lengths(i)
children.label: code_analysis

    end do

    ! Replace characters in lucky positions
    do j = 1, len_cc
        if (lucky(j)) then
            if (to_lower(cc(j:j)) == c_lower) then
                !

                else

So when we read cc with read(*,*) cc, and the input is "Hello", then cc will be "Hello" followed by 995 spaces. So len_trim(cc) will be 5. So the code will process j from 1 to 5.

Fortran doesn't have classes, so I'll need to structure this using modules or subroutines and functions. Let's break down the steps.

But how to translate the Java code's loop:

In Java:

In Fortran, len_cc is the length of cc. So for j from 1 to len_cc, and for each i, l = ss_lengths(i). Check if j + l -1 <= len_cc. Then compare the substring from j to j+l-1 with ss(i). If matches, then mark positions j to j+l-1.

So in the code:

integer, allocatable :: ss_lengths(:)

Wait, but trim removes trailing spaces. The original code treats the entire input string, including spaces? Probably not, since the Java code uses sc.next() which reads the next token (non-whitespace). So in Fortran, when reading, each read(*,*) will read a token (whitespace-separated). So for example, if the input is "hello world", then read(*,*) cc will read "hello", and the next read would get "world".

But in the problem's context, the input for cc is a single token, and c is a single character.

So the code would read:

But each read(*,*) will read a token. For example, if the ss[i] is "AbC", then it will be read into the variable ss(i) as "AbC" with trailing spaces if the variable's length is longer.

But when comparing, we use the ss_lengths(i), so trailing spaces beyond the actual length of the token are ignored.

Wait, no. For example, if the ss(i) variable is declared as length 1000, but the input token is "abc", then ss(i) is "abc" followed by 997 spaces. The len_trim(ss(i)) would be 3, so when comparing, we take the first 3 characters. So the code would compare the first 3 characters of ss(i) (abc) with the substring of cc.

Yes, that's correct.

Now, the output is to print the modified cc.

So, after processing, we need to trim trailing spaces. Because if cc is declared as length 1000, but the actual input was shorter, then the rest would be filled with spaces. So in the code, after processing, take the first len_trim(cc) characters and print them.

But in the Java code, the original cc is the length m. So when reading in Fortran, len_cc = len_trim(cc) gives the actual length.

But during processing, the code should process all characters up to len_cc, even if they are spaces. But in the Java code, sc.next() reads the next token, which is a non-whitespace sequence. So the cc in the Java code does not contain spaces. So in Fortran, when reading cc, it's a single token, so no spaces. So len_cc is the length of the token.

Thus, after processing, the code can print cc(1:len_cc).

Putting it all together.

Now, the code structure in Fortran:

module utils
    implicit none
contains
    logical function is_upper(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        is_upper = (ch >= 'A' .and. ch <= 'Z')
    end function

    character function to_upper(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        if (ch >= 'a' .and. ch <= 'z') then
            to_upper = achar(iachar(ch) - 32)
        else
            to_upper = ch
        end if
    end function

    character function to_lower(ch)
        character, intent(in) :: ch
        if (ch >= 'A' .and. ch <= 'Z') then
            to_lower = achar(iachar(ch) + 32)
        else
            to_lower = ch
        end if
    end function
end module utils

program main
    use utils
    implicit none

    integer :: n, i, j, k, l, len_cc
    character(len=1000), allocatable :: ss(:)
    integer, allocatable :: ss_lengths(:)
    character(len=1000) :: cc, temp_str
    character :: c, c_lower, c_upper, a_char, a_upper, a_lower
    logical, allocatable :: lucky(:)

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) n
    allocate(ss(n), ss_lengths(n))
    do i = 1, n
        read(*,*) temp_str
        ss(i) = temp_str
        ss_lengths(i) = len_trim(ss(i))
    end do

    read(*,*) cc
    read(*,*) c

    ! Preprocess cc length
    len_cc = len_trim(cc)

    ! Determine a_char based on c
    c_lower = to_lower(c)
    if (c_lower == 'a') then
        a_char = 'b'
    else
        a_char = 'a'
    end if
    a_upper = to_upper(a_char)
    a_lower = to_lower(a_char)
    c_upper = to_upper(c)
    c_lower = to_lower(c)

    ! Initialize lucky array
    allocate(lucky(len_cc))
    lucky = .false.

    ! Mark lucky positions
    do j = 1, len_cc
        do i = 1, n
            l = ss_lengths(i)
            if (j + l - 1 > len_cc) cycle
            ! Compare substring j:j+l-1 with ss(i)(1:l)
            do k = 1, l
                if (to_upper(cc(j + k -1:j + k -1)) /= to_upper(ss(i)(k:k))) exit
            end do
            if (k > l) then  ! all characters matched
                do k = j, j + l -1
                    lucky(k) = .true.
                end do
            end if
        end do
    end do

    ! Replace characters in lucky positions
    do j = 1, len_cc
        if (lucky(j)) then
            if (to_lower(cc(j:j)) == c_lower) then
                ! Replace with a_char, preserving case
                if (is_upper(cc(j:j))) then
                    cc(j:j) = a_upper
                else
                    cc(j:j) = a_lower
                end if
            else
                ! Replace with c, preserving case
                if (is_upper(cc(j:j))) then
                    cc(j:j) = c_upper
                else
                    cc(j:j) = c_lower
                end if
            end if
        end if
    end do

    ! Output the result
    write(*, '(a)') trim(cc(1:len_cc))

end program main

Wait, but in Fortran, when you have a character variable of length 1000, and you assign a string shorter than 1000, it is padded with spaces on the right. So when we read cc with read(*,*) cc, and the input is "Hello", then cc will be "Hello" followed by 995 spaces. So len_trim(cc) will be 5. So the code will process j from 1 to 5. The remaining characters are spaces, but since len_cc is 5, they are not processed.

So in the loop for j, it's 1 to len_cc (5 in this case). For each j, check each ss[i].

When comparing, the code compares cc(j:j+l-1) to ss(i)(1:l). But if j + l -1 exceeds len_cc (which is handled by the cycle statement), so that's okay.

Another point: in the code, when checking if the characters match, the loop over k from 1 to l. If all match, then k would be l+1 after the loop. Wait, no. In the code:

do k = 1, l
    if (to_upper(cc(j + k -1:j + k -1)) /= to_upper(ss(i)(k:k))) exit
end do
if (k > l) then

Wait, the loop will exit when the characters are not equal, so k would be at the position where they differ. If all characters match, the loop completes all iterations and k is l+1. So if k > l, then it's a match.

Yes.

Testing this code:

The code would mark any occurrence of a, b, or c in cc. Then replace any lucky positions. For example, if a is one of the ss, then any occurrence of a in cc (case-insensitive) would be marked. Then, since the character c is a, the replacement for a would be 'b'. But need to check.

But this is just to test the code. However, the actual code translation should follow the Java code.

Another possible issue is the treatment of the input. In Java, each ss[i] is read as a token, which is a sequence of non-whitespace characters. So in Fortran, the read(*,*) temp_str will read a token, which is the same.

Thus, this should handle the input correctly.

Finally, the code writes trim(cc(1:len_cc)), which is the original length of cc. Because during processing, the code only modifies characters up to len_cc. Any trailing spaces (due to Fortran's fixed-length strings) are ignored.

So this should correctly translate the Java code to Fortran.
